By MICHAEL MANES
Although Hopkins is
considered by most a very secular
university, it maintains three
Major organizations that deal
specifically with organized
religion.
Among these organizations are
the Office of the Chaplain, an
official University office, the
Jewish Student Association, and
the Catholic Community on
Campus, which is headed by
Father Philip Cunningham. The
latter two receive no University
funds.
According to a poll of .25
random students taken by the
News-Letter, however, only 20
percent of the undergraduates at
Hopkins are actively involved
with an organized religion on
campus, whereas nearly 40
percent claimed they were
actively involved with religious
groups off the campus, such as in
their own home state.
In addition, when asked if
they thought Hopkins students
were 'apathetic about organized
religion on campus, nearly 50
percent said yes, 25 percent said
no, and 25 percent had no
opinion. Finally, when asked of
their opinion of some of the
religions activities on campus, 10
percent said that the activities
were not very good, 25 percent
thought they were very good,
and 65 percent expressed no
opinion—claiming they "did not
know enough" about such
activities as Sunday Experience,
Catholic CoMmunity on campus,
or Jewish Student Association.
When asked about the possible
apathy towards organized
religion on campus, Dean of
Students Robert J. Fitzpatrick
noted that perhaps it would be
an advantage if there were more
clergymen and rabbis on campus

who would be genuinely
interested with the students.
"I think that the organized
religious groups on campus have
not been as strong as expected,"
Fitzpatrick observed.
According to the Office of the
Chaplain, however, over 95% of
the incoming freshmen did
express a religious preference on

breakdown for the class of 1977
is as follows: Jewish 40%, Roman

Catholic 30%, Protestant 25%,
non-denominational 5%.

SC discusses elections and poll
By MARK DALZELL
Leon Barish, Junion Class
representative, attempted
unsuccessfully Tuesday evening
to reintroduce the conflict of
interest question after the
Student Council's unanimous
confirmation of Susan Matson as
Orientation Chairman.
Barish offered a motion which
would have prohibited all
Student Council members from
seeking positions requiring the
approval of the Selections
Committee. His motion was ruled
out of order by Council President
Andy Savitz and not raised again.
Tuesday's Meeting
At the outset of Tuesday's
meeting, the Student Council
moved to lengthen the April
general 'elections an additional
weekend. In effect, the Council's
action reverses a decision reached
earlier in the fall and returns
Hopkins to the previous practice
of having a four week election
period.
In other developments, the

Council declines' to endorse the
lobbying efforts of the
newly-created Issues Committee
before the Maryland General
Assembly until that Committee
identified the specific legislative
proposals on which it wished to
act.
Routinely
The Council routinely
confirmed Susan Matson, Junior
Class representative, as the
Selection. Committee's choice for
next fall's Orientation chairman.
The unanimous approval Matson
received from her Council
colleagues apparetly brought to
an end the controversy which her
candidacy aroused.
Afterwards
After the meeting Nancy
Brighton, Freshman class
representative and the newest
member of the Selections
Committee, reported that she
and the three other members of
the committee had urged Matson
to remain as a member of
Selections. "It can look any way

it wants, she does a fine job,"
Brighton said of Matson.
Student Council President
Andy Savitz was apparetly
satisfied with the response given
to the academic priority poll by
Hopkins undergraduates as he
reported the results of that poll
to the Council on Tuesday
evening.
Of the 600 students who
responded, the overwhelming
majority viewed the upgrading of
undergraduate teaching and in
increase in course offerings as
their major priorities.
Savitz
Savitz did not hesitate to
interpret these findings as being
consistent with Student Council
efforts in the past few weeks,
even though his own proposal for
an A, B, C, no credit grading
system received a sharp rebuke
from the student body. He
declared, "We are continuing
what we have been doing; we
have been right on target all
along."

Sue Matson chosen to head Orientation '74
By ALAN HIRSCh
Sue Matson, a Florida junior
was appointed the 1974
Orientation Chairperson by the
Student Council at the Council's
Tuesday session.
Matson was chosen by the SC
Selection Committee, and then
approved by the entire council,
after the Council decided that
Matson's position on the
Selections Committee would not
interfere with the objective
selection of a chairperson.
No Resignation
"It was the feeling of the
Student Council that if we Could
objectively decide the issue, then
we could go ahead without
Matson's resignation," said
Selections Committee chairman
Bob Lewin.
Matson had agreed to leave the
Selections Committee if SC
sentiment favored her leaving.

However, according to Lewin, no
SC member objected to Matson's
remaining on the Committee
while seeking the position.
Matson did not take part in the
Committee's deliberations on the
Orientation position.
By Far
"Sue [Matson] was the most
qualified person weinterviewed
by far," commented Lewin."So,
there really can't be any doubt,
in this vase. that any bias towards
her influenced our decision," he
added
Only three persons in all
applied for the position—a
disappointing turnout Lewin
said
In deciding on Matson, the
Selections Committee was very
impressed by her concrete ideas
and proposals for next year's
Orientation, Lewin said.
Chief among Matson's aims for

Orientation '74 is to get as many
people involved as possible,
especially undergraduates.
"Everyone should be involved
in this." she remarked.
The principal goal for
orientation next year, Matson
said, ! will be to make the
incoming Freshmen and transfer
students "feel that they're part
of the University as quickly as
possible."
"I think that Orientation
should be continued through at
least the first semester," she
contended. "It takes more time
than a week to make a person
feel he or she is a part of a
place," she also stated
One of the Committee's major
objectives, Matson revealed, will
be to make sure that
"Departmental advisors should
be available for consultation as
soon as Freshmen arrive,"

Matson suggested as one way of
informing students about
academic concerns.
Also, Committees concerning
Freshman placement testing,
instruction on using the Library,
and Registration procedure will
probably be formed, said the
Orientation Chairperson. In

following words of Dr. Sampson,,

I do not wish to take a position
of direct opposition to Dr.
Sampson's belief(quoted earlier in
the article) that "(the minimester)
... has no legal approval, and
should only be on a voluntary,
non-credit system," because I feel
certain that his ideas are based on
good intentions. The minimester is
an important contrast to the rest
of the academic year, and its basic
principles (which I presume to be,
simply, learning with no ulterior
motive except the application of
what's been learned) should be
carefolly guarded.
However, as both a full-time
undergraduate student and a
teacher of one of the minimester
courses, I take as a direct insult
Sampson's contentions that many

of the minimester courses are
"potentially fly-by-night" and a
way of obtaining "extra credits"
Furthermore, his insinuation that
putting pressure on the faculty to
offer more courses is an
undesireable thing, is incredibly
biasesl. Such a position amounts to
blatant ignorance of a student's
desire to learn. This stance may
make for much published paper,
but is academically fatal in the
long run.
The idea of the minimester is to
offer material that is unobtainable
during the regular semester, largely
because of Hopkins'
horse-in-blinders approach to
education. The credit system is
designed to acknowledge a certain
degree of proficiency or skill in
some area of endeavor. Note that
during the regular term, a science
major receives credit for courses in
literature, and vice-versa. That he
should not would be an insult to
both the respective field of study,
and the student's own efforts in
that field. If an entire institution is
run with a credit system, for that
institution not to accredit a course
to me means that it doesn't want
to accept responsibility for the
course. Two reasons for not
accepting this responsibility are:
the course is poortly taught; and
the course is in some trivial field of
endeavor. Thus to abolish the
credit system during the
minimester while retaining it for
the rest of the academic year is
tantamount to officially stating

either poorly taught or of trivial
importance. To go further this

more than trivial importance.

exceeds the credit requirement for
graduation, it's an obvious sign

to take a few courses of his own

volition. These courses are just as
important as any the short-sighted,
shallow and pompous
administrations of this or any
other, university deem as being
"necessary" or "required for
graduation." Meanwhile, if this
student is allowed to graduate at
all it's a sure sign that the
"requirements" were fulfilled
anyhow. Finally, since in order to
receive accreditation of course
must go through a minimal amount
of screening by the University, it
wouldn't be a bad idea at all if all
minimester courses were given only
for credit The screening involved

would insure that the University's
facilities were being used as
thoroughly and as intelligently as
possible.

I do not wish to take a position

Sampson's belief(quoted earlier in
the article) that "(the minimester)
... has no legal approval, and
should only be on a voluntary,
non-credit system," because I feel
certain that his ideas are based on
good intentions. The minimester is
an important contrast to the rest
of the academic year, and its basic
principles (which I presume to be,
simply, learning with no ulterior
motive except the application of
what's been learned) should be
carefolly guarded.
However, as both a full-time
undergraduate student and a
teacher of one of the minimester
courses, I take as a direct insult
Sampson's contentions that many

of the minimester courses are
"potentially fly-by-night" and a
way of obtaining "extra credits"
Furthermore, his insinuation that
putting pressure on the faculty to
offer more courses is an
undesireable thing, is incredibly
biasesl. Such a position amounts to
blatant ignorance of a student's
desire to learn. This stance may
make for much published paper,
but is academically fatal in the
long run.
The idea of the minimester is to
offer material that is unobtainable
during the regular semester, largely
because of Hopkins'
horse-in-blinders approach to
education. The credit system is
designed to acknowledge a certain
degree of proficiency or skill in
some area of endeavor. Note that
during the regular term, a science
major receives credit for courses in
literature, and vice-versa. That he
should not would be an insult to
both the respective field of study,
and the student's own efforts in
that field. If an entire institution is
run with a credit system, for that
institution not to accredit a course
to me means that it doesn't want
to accept responsibility for the
course. Two reasons for not
accepting this responsibility are:
the course is poortly taught; and
the course is in some trivial field of
endeavor. Thus to abolish the
credit system during the
minimester while retaining it for
the rest of the academic year is
tantamount to officially stating
that all minimester courses are
either poorly taught or of trivial
importance. To go further this
implies that only those courses

taught during the regular year are
more than trivial importance.

taught during the regular year, Dr.
Sampson's no-credit minimester

to a Hopkins undergraduate, or
truly worth his while to take, are
already being offered. This is true.
Oh, Come, All ye Robots!

acquire "Extra credits." If one
exceeds the credit requirement for
graduation, it's an obvious sign
that the student concerned wished
to take a few courses of his own

volition. These courses are just as
important as any the short-sighted,
shallow and pompous
administrations of this or any
other, university deem as being
"necessary" or "required for
graduation." Meanwhile, if this
student is allowed to graduate at
all it's a sure sign that the
"requirements" were fulfilled
anyhow. Finally, since in order to
receive accreditation of course
must go through a minimal amount
of screening by the University, it
wouldn't be a bad idea at all if all
minimester courses were given only
for credit The screening involved

would insure that the University's
facilities were being used as
thoroughly and as intelligently as
possible.

"The Guy Must Need a Haircut!"
